etymologies: mid 19th century; earliest use found in American Journal of Science. From French phloridzin or its etymon German Phloridzin from ancient Greek ϕλοιός bark + ῥίζα root + German -in

definitions: A crystalline compound, C₂₁ H₂₄ O₁₀, which is a glucoside of phloretin, occurs widely in apple and other fruit trees, and acts biochemically as an uncoupler.
